Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2014 07:57PM MinaBee wrote: From my experience last week, I wasted time worrying over the pain of the isotope injection!  I made the mistake of googling it and read that it was painful then noticed the post was from 2004.  The actual injection was about 10 seconds of a tolerable burning sensation.  For me it was uneventful in the grand scheme of everything else going on.   My BS estimates a 2% chance of lymphedema for each LN removed.  I had 3 SLN removed so by his theory I have a 6% chance, but I considered that all secondary and let him do what needed to be done.   As everyone else has said, the priority is to get an accurate picture of your situation.  My BS also had the "preliminary" testing done during my surgery to reduce the likelihood of a second surgery for more tissue/nodes. My final path report agreed with the preliminary so no second surgery.   Nao - Good luck with your decision on which BS to go with, I hope you find a sense of confidence with one of them!

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2014 08:12PM MinaBee wrote: Faerywings - My LX was 11 days ago and I too went bra shopping before hand and was glad I had a few to choose from after surgery.  Hospital sent me home with their velcro bra that I only tolerated for a few hours.  I found a front zip bra on Amazon (Valmont - $18) that was on my doorstep when we got home from surgery and I wore it continuously the first few days.  Then I was able to switch to the other new non-underwire bras (from Kohls) during the day and am still sleeping in the Valmont at night (front zip = no uncomfy hooks on your back while you sleep).  I was also planning on returning the unused bras, but was surprised to find the one I was sure I'd return was the most comfy for day wear.  I guess the point is I bought different style bras because you just don't know which one will be comfy during recovery (as long as know you can return them).  I found that the 20 year old sports bra that was perfect after the biopsy was very uncomfortable after surgery.  I also stocked up on ice packs - found having three in rotation worked for me - I bought the CVS brand that had a cloth sleeve so the plastic wasn't directly on my skin.  Lastly, I suggest making sure you have lots of button or zip front tops on hand, I lived in old flannel shirts the first week and got a couple nice zip sweaters on the end-of-season clearance racks for work this week - still haven't pulled a top over my head easily without help.   All the best to you!! Cindy - I love the tip about the soft sock, think I'll go try that now - for some reason today's bra bothered me when it was ok a few days ago!  I must have fickle breasts!
